comments.commentBody: Until now, the only tea garden I had ever heard of was Jack Teagarden, the jazz musician. I usually learn something from crosswords, and this was no exception.

I had to do some backtracking at the end to entice Mr Happy Pencil to join the party but he popped in with a smile on his face. I'm embarrassed to say that I wasn't sure of Strauss-Kahn's name -- guess I wasn't paying attention. Ian, you get an Aww from me.

Is there such a thing as Scotch Pong? Or Mike's Hard Lime Pong?

So far every terrorist the NYPD seems to find is mentally unstable, poor, desperately lonely and entirely unable to even conceive of any attack unless it is suggested by a police informant, underwhelmed, bloomberg we see through your tired attempt to revive post 9/11 deference to authority, it won't work

Starbucks intentionally makes restrooms available as a way of building up business. In Manhattan, there is a Starbucks every other corner. So when you gotta go in Manhattan, as long as that nearby Strbucks is still open, you got a place to go. Nice convenience, and I have spent money at Starbucks just because it's nice to return the favor. If employees object because the task of keeping the restrooms clean is onerous, they can get a job some place where there are no public restrooms.

Baristas:  Don't lock them, just refuse to clean them.  You have no obligation to clean up after pigs.  Does Starbucks really expect you to do this?  If it were me and anyone complained, I would say, "I'm sorry, the customer before you took a messy dump and spooged on the tiles.  What do you want me to do?  I make coffee."

So, why not build self-cleaning restrooms (Automated Public Toilets) into Starbucks?  That'd solve the demeaning, disgusting, and unsanitary task of having to clean the toilets; and it'd make it more pleasant for patrons.

I guess it was good to get rid of Mubarak but I hope all those who advocated popular revolution-Arab Spring-are paying attention to the aftermath.  Revolutionaries cannot govern and chaos begets chaos.  Just sayin'.
The sooner tourism is restored the better! Hoards of visitors will flow to check out all those antique sites

What seemed promise now fails. Egypt is a portrait of volatility, injustice, and poverty. A greedy few dominate most of the economy and the military. The greatest wealth is the oppressed people and the greatest waste is those same human beings. Egypt is the residue of colonialism and failed anti-colonialism that became subservient to political powers outside Egypt.

I recommend that readers study Professor Gary Nash’s work on the American Revolution and think seriously and soundly about the enormous wisdom, energy, and luck building from a revolution takes. Not everyone benefitted immediately or even long term from the American Revolution, though creative forces did emerge.

Egypt ought to become a great nation again. The source of that greatness would be to open opportunity to everyone and that is not something any one of us does well.
Tell a lie enough times.......

While I agree with some of the points made in Comment 41 by Ken W, I have to disagree with his ready acceptance of the allegation that "the Ottoman Empire ... perpetrated ... genocide" against the Armenians.

As an outsider who has read the accounts of those tragic times, I have yet to come across any conclusive uncontested or incontrovertible documentary evidence that the Ottoman Sultan or any member of his government ever gave orders for the "the deliberate and systematic destruction, in whole or in part, of (the Armenians) as an ethnic, racial, religious, or national group", the definition of genocide.

Certainly there were massacres on both sides during a time of war in which groups of armed Armenian nationalists were seeking to use the Ottoman-Russian conflict to form an independent nation (much like the Kurds today); but there has never been any evidence provided of a plan by the Ottoman rulers to destroy all the Armenian subjects in their empire.

The best evidence to the contrary is the fact that none of the millions of Armenians living in Turkish cities such as Constantinople or Smyrna were harmed, and only about 2,345 political agitators in Constantinople were deported. It was primarily the large numbers of Armenians living near the Eastern front who were forcibly relocated to Syria in order to stop the armed partisans among them from joining the attacking Russians.

There is a sad irony in reading the postings of some pro-Armenian commentators defending the Kurds. They appear to be ignorant of the fact that many of the massacres of Armenians nearly a century ago were perpetrated by the Kurds:

http://www.armeniapedia.org/index.php?title=Kurds_Massacre_More_Armenian...

Furthermore, at the end of WW1 the victorious British took 141 Turkish leaders to Malta to be tried for war crimes including several suspected of being complicit in the Armenian deaths. Yet, every single one of them was later released due to lack of evidence.
When workers are no longer tied to their jobs just for the health benefits, we will see the corporations start their well deserved decline.

Some people may not realize it, but business doesn't want cash laying around unused. They do not accumulate cash to hoard it.
They also will not hire employees or expand facilities, unless they see an opportunity to profit by doing so.
There is nothing evil in that. Businesses need to survive to be of benefit to any of us, and they will not do that by keeping persons on the payroll and manufacturing products they cannot sell.

"The BBC's Lucy Williamson in Seoul says passing it was seen as a risky move because with elections due next year, many voters already say they feel alienated by the big parties' bullish tactics." I couldn't agree more. Seoul's incumbent leadership is practically irrelevant. Don't bet on it!

There's nothing out there.

It's only on earth so better learn how to get along with each other.

Our hubris should disappear as we realize it's only us and our Creator.

A brilliant horror romance. Like a creepy Henry James short story. Almost Lynchian (David) in its portrait of American paranoia & defensive arrogance. And o what a tragic love story. Eastwood is so very good.

Who would have thought a movie about this character could be so dreary and dull?  But Eastwood is one of the most overrated directors on the planet, and his actors just don't seem to know what they are supposed to do, as is often the case.   Black has turned out a flat, colorless screenplay, as well.  Leo D. works like a demon, and is actually quite convincing, and the rest of the cast does its best,  but to no avail.  And the make up!!  Clearly Leo got the entire budget in that department---poor Armie Hammer as the old Clyde Tolson looks like one of the aliens from Buckaroo Banzai....or James Caan at the end of For the Boys.
It is backwards.  "30 grams flour, 20 grams fat" is correct.
You should consider cooking the family and serving it to the bird.

Oh Lordie. Would everyone be carrying on if someone said to a dinner guest "how French of you." Or, "how English of you." That was not an ethnic slur. Ridiculous. PC run amok.

And no, I do not like to share my food, and loathe the practice.
Somehow I feel that the fact that the boast about the caul fat precedes the complaint about the family suggests misplaced priorities ...

The National Security debate is bringing out a war-hawk element of some in the Republican candidates. Huntsman, seemingly intelligent and knowledgeable of many foreign topics, has advocated more drone strikes in Pakistan. Not saying what he is trying to accomplish. To kill all Muslims we feel are terrorist? Must be something that rubbed off from President Obama, as Obama's Ambassador to China.

Newt Gingrich, in his wisdom, announced that if the Pakistani leadership cannot control the radical Muslims in their own country, said..."They should get out of the way"...letting us go in and do the job for them. It is strangely similar to what candidate Obama said in a debate, that as president he would go into Pakistan with military might to fight the terrorist problem in their country. He is doing just that with his unmanned drones, and the terrorist threat is growing.

It is not hard to understand that the drone attacks create more new terrorist than those we are killing. The more drone attacks, the more newly motivated terrorists grows exponentially. The mastermind of 9/11 is dead...yet we perpetuate his very existence with the drones.

Newt Gingrich,again, the newly heralded Romney alternate said...he would bomb Iran, if everything else failed in stopping them from making a nuclear bomb, soley ,with the intent to cause regime change.

There is a power struggle in that part of the Muslim World...a Sunni, Shia thing...we are becoming dangerously involved in their internal disputes. A note of warning came from Karzai, the leader of Afghanistan, when he said...if there was a Pakistani war against America, he would side with Pakistan. Our shortsighted policies in that area could unite the Shiites and the Sunnis...an Islamic coalition...an Osama bin Laden dream come true.

President Obama has failed miserably in soothing tensions in the Middle East and now in Northern Africa...it seems that now, some of the Republican candidates are prone to follow Obama's lead.

People, get a life.

Your children and grandchildren have told you that they are able to come for Thanksgiving dinner after all.

Lucky you!!

We told my wife's family that we were spending a quiet thanksgiving at home with our new baby. My wife's mother insisted we drive 60 miles to a nearby city to join the family as usual, for what is always the worst food you will ever taste, the most boring conversation you will ever have and the company of a few of the most crazy people you'll ever meet. No one drinks even wine because they think they're religious and alcohol comes from satan. Then we drive 60 miles back home and keep our two beautiful dogs waiting alone for eight hours. Not on your life.

At times, it's just not worth the effort. We'll be staying home with a new baby, a warm fire, a very good bottle of wine, great food, easy conversation and our pups asleep at our feet. No one will guilt us out of that. Especially my mother in law.

I just pick at the turkey bits each time I walk through the kitchen and peek my head into the fridge (a reflex for young men).

I find that this usually takes care of the problem pretty quickly.
